ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would summarize French 231 as an exploration of Quebec culture. Professor Cayer seemed intent on giving us background of Canadian history, literature, as well as music culture, and even current events, a combination that was very well-rounded.

Yes, without hesitation. You won't often have the chance to learn about this region and read French-Canadian literature. Prof. Cayer does an excellent job including some background information (you don't need to know anything about Canadian history or culture going in) and gives lots of individual attention to his students. Assignments were creative and gave lots students plenty of freedom to choose their own topic.

Yes, absolutely. Professor Cayer is a great instructor, which only makes his already impressive syllabus even stronger. This course is great in that it is unique in the French department's offerings. The global regions on which the French department's courses focus are typically France, North Africa (history of French colonization), and the Caribbean (history French colonization). One of the major francophone regions - Quebec and Canada - are very rarely the focus of courses in the department due to the faculty's current areas of expertise. I knew I wanted to take this course when I first saw it listed last summer, and it absolutely lived up to my expectations.

Definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to keep up their French skills. Also highly recommend it to anyone interested in American studies because Quebec's culture offers a unique perspective on the United States.
